questions.text: In the 1920s, Otto Warburg observed that cancerous cells consume a lot of glucose and produce a lot of lactate even in the presence of sufficient oxygen. This effect observed in cancerous cells is also referred to as:

options.label: D
options.text: Inhibition of oxygen uptake by glycolysis

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aerobic glycolysis In cancer cells, pyruvate is converted to lactate even in the presence of O 2 . This is known as the Warburg effect or aerobic glycolysis. Lactic acid makes the local environment acidic helping in metastasis. Energy derived from the conversion of pyruvate to lactate is just 2 ATPs, so, cancer cells take up a large amount of glucose compared to normal cells. This leads to glucose wastage by cells and weight loss (cachexia).

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option B: Anaerobic glycolysis The glycolysis occurring under the absence of oxygen is known as anaerobic glycolysis e.g. glycolysis in exercising muscle. This process also produces lactic acid as the end-product by converting pyruvate to lactate using the enzyme LDH and regenerates NAD from NADH that is required to keep the glycolysis going. Option C: Inhibition of glycolysis by oxygen This is known as Pasteur’s effect. In this effect, in the presence of oxygen, anaerobic glycolysis (simply known as glycolysis) is inhibited. It saves the wastage of glucose. Option D: Inhibition of oxygen uptake by glycolysis This is known as the Crabtree effect and is mainly observed in ethanol-fermenting yeast such as Saccharomyces cerevisiae. When the O2 supply is kept constant & glucose concentration is increased, then the O 2 consumption by cell falls.

questions.text: The polyol pathway plays an important role in meeting the energy requirements of seminal vesicles because it is responsible for the formation of which of following:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fructose from glucose This is a short pathway to synthesize fructose in the body via sorbitol. First glucose is reduced to its alcohol i.e. sorbitol (or glucitol) by the enzyme aldose reductase (the same enzyme which reduces galactose to galactitol). Then sorbitol is oxidized to fructose by the enzyme sorbitol dehydrogenase. This synthesis of fructose in the body is especially useful in seminal vesicles for sperms as they mainly use fructose as the source of energy.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Options B, C, and D: Galactose from glucose and fructose and glucose from fructose These reactions do not occur in the body.

questions.text: Net ATPs produced by when one molecule of fructose is converted to two molecules of pyruvate?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2 The ATP yield of fructose is the same as that of glucose. One may argue that fructose enters glycolysis bypassing the energy investment step (fructose-1-phosphate to fructose 1,6 bisphosphate) and thus 1 ATP should be obtained extra. but one extra ATP is used for the conversion of glyceraldehyde to GAP. So, ATP consumption (total 2 per fructose) is the same as glycolysis of glucose. Look at the ATP used in kinase reaction in the image when fructose enters glycolysis. Hence Net ATP yield is also 4 ATP produced- 2 ATP used = 2 ATPs

questions.text: Which one of the following statements about the metabolism of carbohydrates is correct?

options.label: B
options.text: Fructose is an aldose sugar like glucose.

options.label: C
options.text: Fructose transport into cells is insulin dependent.

options.label: D
options.text: Galactose is phosphorylated to galactose-1-phosphate by galactokinase

questions.correct_answer: D. Galactose is phosphorylated to galactose-1-phosphate by galactokinase
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Galactose is phosphorylated to galactose-1-phosphate by galactokinase Galactokinase catalyzes the first step of galactose breakdown. It catalyzes the phosphorylation of the C1 alcohol group of galactose to produce galactose-1-phosphate. The deficiency of this enzyme results in the accumulation of galactose and is known as minor type galactosemia.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A: Fructokinase phosphorylates fructose to fructose-6-phosphate Fructokinase the first enzyme of fructose breakdown phosphorylates fructose to fructose-1-phosphate using ATP. Option B: Fructose is an aldose sugar like glucose Fructose is a ketohexose whereas glucose is an aldohexose. It has a keto group at the C2 position. In cyclic form, this keto group forms a bond with C5 and gives rise to a five-membered ring known as furanose. Option C: Fructose transport into cells is insulin-dependent. Fructose is transported into intestinal cells by an insulin-independent GLUT-5 transporter. Insulin-dependent transporter is GLUT-4 which gets activated in a fed state and transports glucose to peripheral cells.

questions.text: Snowflake cataract is produced because of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aldose reductase In diabetics, excess glucose freely enters the cells of the eye which are highly permeable to glucose. Here, glucose is reduced by the aldose reductase enzyme to produce sorbitol/polyol. In other cells, this sorbitol is oxidized to keto sugar fructose by the enzyme sorbitol dehydrogenase, but this enzyme is absent in the eye, hence sorbitol accumulation occurs. Sorbitol is hygroscopic in nature and absorbs water causing swelling of the cells. Swelling due to excess sorbitol in the lens ultimately leads to snowflake cataract .

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option B: Galactose reductase This enzyme does the same reaction as aldose reductase but works specifically on galactose to produce galactitol The galactitol accumulation in the eyes causes oil-drop cataract in galactosemic patients. Option C: Fructose dehydrogenase This is a bacterial enzyme and is not present in humans. It performs 2 electron oxidation of D-fructose to 2-keto-D-fructose. Option D: Alcohol dehydrogenase Alcohol dehydrogenase is a common enzyme involved in the metabolism and detoxification of alcohol It catalyzes the oxidation of any alcohol to its aldehyde form e.g. ethanol to acetaldehyde and methanol to formaldehyde These relatively toxic aldehydes are further oxidized to their harmless acid form by respective aldehyde dehydrogenases. In diabetics, excess glucose entering the insulin-insensitive tissues such as the eye gets converted to sugar alcohol sorbitol by the enzyme aldose reductase. The hygroscopic sorbitol accumulation ultimately causes formation of snowflake cataract.

questions.text: Essential pentosuria is due to a deficiency of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Xylulose reductase Essential Pentosuria can occur due to a deficiency of either of these two enzymes: Xylulose reductase Xylitol dehydrogenase These enzymes are part of minor pathways of glucose oxidation known as the uronic acid pathway (see attached treasure) Diagnostic features: L-xylulose accumulates and comes out in urine, which gives a positive Benedict’s test as it is a reducing sugar, but the glucose oxidase test strip is negative. Symptoms appear due to the consumption of a large amount of fruits that are rich in pentoses. It is a part of Garrod's tetrad (see attached treasure)

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A: Fructokinase Fructokinase deficiency causes essential fructosuria, not essential pentosuria. It’s a benign condition with excess fructose coming out in the urine. Option B: Phosphoglucomutase (PGM) It’s a common enzyme of glycogenesis and glycogenolysis and interconverts glucose-1-P and glucose-6-P PGM1 deficiency aka CDG syndrome or GSD type XIV is a rare inherited metabolic disorder with poorly defined symptoms such as dilated cardiomyopathy, exercise intolerance, and hepatopathy. Option D: Gluconolactone oxidase This enzyme is also part of uronic acid but only in plants and not in humans. It converts L-gluconolactone to L-ascorbic acid (vitamin C). Essential pentosuria is caused by a deficiency of enzymes xylulose reductase or xylitol dehydrogenase of the uronic acid pathway causing accumulation of their pentose substrates xylulose and xylitol and their excretion in urine

questions.text: What is the enzyme involved in the following conversion?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aldose reductase Monosaccharides get converted to their respective alcohols on reduction. Glucose gets converted to its alcohol i.e. s orbitol . Galactose is converted to its alcohol i.e. galactitol . In both cases, a common enzyme aldose reductase is used (see fig.)

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A: Sorbitol dehydrogenase It carries out oxidation of sorbitol to fructose using NAD as an electron acceptor. It is important in some cells such as sperm cell that uses fructose as its major fuel for energy. Option B: Glucose reductase There is no such enzyme as Glucose reductase in humans. This function of reduction is performed by aldose reductase. Option D: Glucose oxidase This is a fungal enzyme and is used for glucose estimation by the GOD-POD test. It oxidizes glucose to produce gluconolactone and H 2 O 2 amount of which can be detected using POD and in a coloring reaction.

questions.text: Familial fructokinase deficiency causes no symptoms because:

options.label: C
options.text: Excess fructose does not escape into the urine

options.label: D
options.text: Excess fructose is excreted through feces

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hexokinase can phosphorylate fructose Fructose metabolism Fructokinase is the first enzyme for fructose metabolism and it converts fructose to fructose-1-P. In Fructokinase deficiency , Hexokinase (a non-specific enzyme) can phosphorylate fructose and glucose but it has a low affinity (high km) for fructose. Glucose is the true substrate for hexokinase. Fructose-6-phosphate formed by hexokinase reaction can enter the glycolytic pathway, so, it does not accumulate to produce toxic effects.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option B: The liver aldolase can metabolize it Liver aldolase enzyme cleaves fructose-1,6-bisphosphate to DHAP and glyceraldehyde-3-P Liver aldolase B also cleaves fructose-1-P to DHAP and glyceraldehyde. Options C and D: Excess fructose does not escape into the urine, Excess fructose is excreted through feces The excess fructose from the peripheral tissues is excreted into the blood and then filtered in urine. Fructose is completely absorbed from food as there is no problem in absorption, so it is not excreted in feces. Option D: Excess fructose is converted to glucose Fructose cannot be converted to glucose as aldose reductase is not found in the liver

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with type I (IDDM) diabetes went to an ophthalmologist for an assessment of developing a cataract. The results of his blood work are shown below: Which of the following enzymes is most strongly associated with cataract formation in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aldose reductase The blood examination with high fasting glucose (>126 mg/dl) and HBA1c >6.5% along with urine ketone bodies and urine glucose indicate a diabetic condition. In diabetic patients, excess blood glucose enters insulin-insensitive tissues and leads to the formation of sorbitol by aldose reductase. But sorbitol dehydrogenase is absent in most of these cells and sorbitol cannot be converted to fructose. Hence, sorbitol accumulation occurs. As sorbitol is hygroscopic and will absorb water causing cell swelling ultimately leading to snowflake cataract in diabetic patients (see fig).

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A: Glucokinase Glucokinase is an enzyme of glycolysis and defects in these enzymes generally manifest as hemolysis and anemia. Here, normal hemoglobin indicates no glucokinase deficiency. Option C: Aldolase B Aldolase B is involved in fructose metabolism and its deficiency causes fructose intolerance with symptoms such as hepatomegaly, jaundice, and hypoglycemia but no cataract. Option D: Galactokinase Galactokinase is an enzyme of galactose metabolism. Its deficiency causes galactosemia. In galactosemia, this same enzyme converts excess galactose to galactitol accumulation of which in the eye causes oil-drop cataract. In diabetics, excess glucose entering the insulin-insensitive tissues such as the eye gets converted to sugar alcohol sorbitol by the enzyme aldose reductase. The hygroscopic sorbitol accumulation ultimately causes the formation of snowflake cataract.

questions.text: Biological dehydrogenation reactions are enzyme-catalyzed oxidation-reduction reactions where one molecule loses hydrogen or electrons and other molecule accept it. Most of the time the cofactor of the enzyme plays a role as an electron acceptor or donor. Which vitamin as a coenzyme is required for glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Niacin Niacin is a pyridine derivative. Coenzyme forms: NADP + , NAD + These coenzyme forms are involved in a variety of oxidation-reduction reactions as a part of oxidoreductases enzymes e.g. (see table below) Enzyme Coenzyme Isocitrate dehydrogenase NAD + α-Ketoglutarate dehydrogenase NAD + Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase NADP + Malate dehydrogenase NAD + Glutamate dehydrogenase NAD + Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase NAD + or NADP + Lactate dehydrogenase NAD + Alcohol dehydrogenase NAD +

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A: Riboflavin The coenzyme forms of riboflavin are FAD and FMN They are also involved in oxidation-reduction reactions e.g. succinate dehydrogenase, fatty acyl CoA dehydrogenase Option B: Thiamine Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) is the active coenzyme form of thiamine It is used by the enzymes pyruvate dehydrogenase complex and α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase for oxidative decarboxylation. Option D: Biotin Biotin serves as an essential cofactor for all carboxylase enzymes such as pyruvate carboxylase, acetyl-CoA carboxylase, propionyl-CoA carboxylase, and 3-methylcrotonyl-CoA-carboxylase

questions.text: Patient of 34 years of age was reported in the hospital with complaints of fatigue, dizziness, nausea, and headache past 4 days. Upon examination, pallor was noted in the conjunctiva, palm, and nail beds. The liver is tender and palpable. History of the patient revealed intake of a fixed-dose combination of trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole (Septran DS) 10 days earlier on the prescription of a physician for treatment of sore throat. Microscopic blood examination indicates a nonspherocytic and normocytic anemia which most probably is a due reduction in the synthesis of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

NADPH The patient has glucose 6-P dehydrogenase deficiency and cannot generate NADPH from glucose 6-P. In the red blood cells, which lack mitochondria, this is the only pathway through which NADPH can be generated. In the absence of NADPH, the molecule which protects against oxidative damage (glutathione) is oxidized preferentially to protect membrane lipids and proteins. There is only limited glutathione in the membrane, so once it is oxidized, it needs to be converted back to reduced glutathione (the protective form). The enzyme that does this, glutathione reductase, requires NADPH to supply the electrons to reduce the oxidized glutathione. In the absence of NADPH, the glutathione cannot be reduced (Option D is false) , and the protection offered by reduced glutathione is eliminated, leading to membrane damage and cell lysis.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- In G6PD deficiency, there will be no effect on NADH as this enzyme does not produce or use NADH. Also, the NADP will be increased due to its non-reduction of NADPH.

questions.text: The HMP pathway consists of two phases known as oxidative and non-oxidative phases. The oxidation of glucose by this pathway produces which of the following as final products?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

6 NADPH In the oxidative phase, 2 NADPH are produced from 1 glucose molecule to give a final product of ribulose-5-P. Now to complete the non-oxidative phase, at least three molecules of ribulose-5-P need to enter this phase (see fig in treasure attached). To form three ribulose-5-P, 3 glucose 6-P will need to be oxidized initially out of which 2 molecules are recovered again at the end. Hence, the total reaction of HMP pathway can be written as: So, in net reaction, a single molecule of glucose is broken into glyceraldehyde-3-P and 3 CO2 and 6 NADPH or, for a complete cycle with 3glucose-6-P molecules, 6NADPH are produced Or we can say, the final products of HMP are 6NADPH.

questions.text: An infant of age 8 months was taken to the clinic of a pediatrician. The infant was restless and crying. Vomitus was noted on the clothes of the infant. Parents gave a history of periodic abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea that started after the weaning of the nfant with fruit juices and corn syrup past month. Upon physical examination, hepatomegaly was evident. Laboratory investigation revealed the presence of reducing sugar upon analysis by the Seliwanoff reagent. Select the deficient enzyme in the body of the infant under the above-mentioned clinical manifestations?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aldolase B deficiency The deficiency of aldolase B results in failure to split fructose-1-phosphate into DHAP and glyceraldehyde 3P. As a result, fructose 1P accumulates in body tissues involving irreversible injury to the liver (hepatomegaly). This condition is called hereditary fructose intolerance, which is a severe form of disorder requiring medical attention. Fructose can be estimated in urine by the Seliwanoff test that is meant for ketohexose only.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: A. A deficiency of fructokinase results in the failure of phosphorylation of fructose and it accumulates in body tissues. It is called essential fructosuria and is a benign disorder. It does not involve liver enlargement. Option: C. Galactokinase deficiency results in the failure of phosphorylation of Galactose into Galactose 1-P. It accumulates in body tissues resulting in galactosemia and galactosuria. Option: D. Glucose 6-phosphatase deficiency results in the accumulation of glycogen in liver cells. It is called type 1 glycogen storage disease. It is manifested as growth retardation, poor tolerance to fasting, and hepatomegaly.

questions.text: Hexose monophosphate (HMP) shunt is an alternative pathway for the oxidation of glucose mainly used for the synthesis of NADPH and ribose 5-P required in synthetic reactions. The number of ATPs produced by HMP shunt is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Zero HMP shunt/ Pentose Phosphate pathway It is one of the alternative pathways to glycolysis for glucose utilization. It neither produces nor utilizes ATPs (see attached treasure). 2 main products of HMP shunt are: NADPH → in the irreversible oxidative phase Ribose-5-phosphate → in reversible non-oxidative phase

questions.text: Identify A and B enzymes in the given figure:
questions.correct_answer: A. Glutathione peroxidase and Glutathione reductase
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glutathione peroxidase and Glutathione reductase In RBCs, HMP forms NADPH. It is used to reduce oxidized glutathione and, in the process, itself gets oxidized (removal of hydrogen) to NADP. The enzyme involved is glutathione reductase , which requires FAD (or Vit B 2 ). So, the function of HMP in RBCs is to produce this reduced glutathione which is used to destroy H 2 O 2 . Now glutathione gets oxidized again by the reduction of H 2 O 2 to harmless water. The enzyme involved is glutathione peroxidase , which is a selenoprotein (requires selenocysteine, the 21st amino acid at its active site).

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option B and D: Glutathione oxidase and Glutathione reductase Glutathione oxidase performs a similar reaction to glutathione peroxidase but the substrate is O 2 instead of H 2 O 2 and the product is H 2 O 2 instead of water. 2 glutathione + O 2 → glutathione disulfide + H 2 O 2 It is found in some microorganisms e.g. Penicillium

questions.text: An infant of age 4 months is breastfeeding. Suddenly, the infant developed disliking to feed, vomiting, and restlessness. The body weight of infant started to decline. The parents brought the infant to the pediatrician for consultation. Upon examination, the physician observed hepatomegaly, jaundice, and bilateral cataract. Select the deficient enzyme responsible for the clinical manifestations in the infant?
questions.correct_answer: A. Deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase Galactose is produced in the intestine from the degradation of milk sugar lactose by the enzyme lactase. The patient’s symptoms suggest it to be a case of classic galactosemia which is due to a deficiency of enzyme Galactose 1-phosphate uridyltransferase of galactose metabolism. Excess Gal accumulation occurs in this disease in the liver causing jaundice, vomiting, hepatomegaly, and in the brain causing mental retardation. Other clinical features include a high risk of E.coli sepsis (reason unknown) and Oil-drop cataract due to inhibition of galactokinase by product inhibition as shown in the figure in the text.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: B. Fructokinase deficiency results in manifestations of benign fructosuria Option: C. Deficiency of aldolase B results in manifestations of hereditary fructose intolerance Option: D. Glucose 6-P dehydrogenase deficiency results in manifestations of hemolytic anemia.
